I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Ministry of Taxes (MOT) 
and the Ministry of Finance (MOF) of the Republic of Azerbaijan to strengthen tax revenue 
administration and policy analysis capacity to mobilize domestic resources to lessen fiscal 
dependence on oil revenues. The TA will provide services and operational support to help both 
ministries design tax administration and policy reforms. The proposed coverage areas are (i) 
human resource management, (ii) taxpayer compliance, and (iii) tax revenue analysis and 
modeling. The TA will also provide support on capacity development plans. 
 
2.  The TA is consistent with Asian Development Bank (ADB) engagement in Azerbaijan, as 
reflected in the country partnership strategy, 2019–2023, and is aligned to Azerbaijan’s Strategic 
Roadmap of National Economic Perspectives and the 2030 agenda for sustainable development.1 
The TA will directly contribute to ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priority of strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity and ADB’s country partnership strategy objective of the 
economic diversification for Azerbaijan.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Recent tax revenue performance. Tax revenues in Azerbaijan as a percentage of gross 
domestic product fell from 11.6% in 2016 to 9.9% in 2017 and 9.3% in 2018, below that of 
comparative countries in Central and West Asia—19.8% for Kyrgyz Republic and 25.7% for 
Georgia in 2017 and an average of 17.3% for Asia and the Pacific.3 The state budget depends 
highly on transfers from the State Oil Fund of the Republic of Azerbaijan, which transferred 
AZN11.35 billion (58.2% of state budget revenues) to the state budget in 2013, and AZN6.10 
billion (36.9% of state budget revenues) in 2017.4 The state budget’s reliance on oil revenues has 
made the economy vulnerable to external shocks. Recognizing this problem, the government has 
focused on strengthening tax policy and administration capacity in non-oil sectors and has 
implemented several tax reforms, including introducing an advance tax ruling concept and the 
concept of voluntary tax disclosure, modifying value-added tax (VAT) rules, and promoting 
cashless payments. 
 
4.  Changes in the operating environment. The rapid globalization and digitalization of 
financial services, investment, and trade has impacted the revenue base. The existence of a 
perceived large informal economy and the growth of e-commerce significantly undermine tax 
collection. The government has demonstrated support and commitment to modernizing tax 
administration and more formally recognizing taxpayers’ rights and service expectations. In May 
2019, the first taxation ombudsman was appointed under the MOT. Further, the government 
recently amended the tax law to encourage compliance and to support a better balance between

the rights of taxpayers and the powers of the tax administration. The MOT developed and publicly 
communicated high-level reform priorities designed to better help taxpayers to comply, build 
taxpayer and staff satisfaction, and strengthen revenue by dealing more effectively with areas of 
non-compliance. Progress is already evident on a number of fronts, including steadily and 
consistently  improving  indicators  for  the  ease  of  doing  business,  because  of  streamlined 
administrative processes such as registration and payment.5 These reforms have been driven by 
the MOT’s strong commitment to critically review key functions and implement measures to 
address identified weaknesses.  
 
5.  Human resource and organizational performance management. For effective tax 
administration,  the  authorities  need  to  strengthen  tax  officers’  capacity.  Staff  training  and 
education are central parts of effective tax administration, which can serve as a tool for attracting, 
developing, and retaining talent, as well as for improving the effectiveness of administration. 
Despite past capacity building support from development partners, the MOT’s tax administration 
capacity  remains  weak,  in  large  part  because  it  lacks  a systematic and  organization-wide 
competency management system. Poor recruitment processes exacerbate this issue. Frequent 
turnover of key officials, driven in part by an inadequate human resources framework, undermines 
sustained efforts for better tax policy and administration. 
 
6.  Increasing the effectiveness of compliance risk management. Effectively managing 
compliance risk involves (i) providing user-friendly support and services for taxpayers who want 
to comply and (ii) dealing more effectively with taxpayers who do not comply. Both are crucial. 
Taxpayers often cannot easily access or understand current services and communications. In 
dealing with non-compliance, the MOT does not often target the highest risks to revenue or firmly 
address the most serious incidents on non-compliance. 
 
7.  Supporting voluntary compliance with better facilitation, education, and services. 
Taxpayers need support and advice to help them meet their tax obligations. To maximize 
voluntary compliance, tax authority must provide taxpayers with information, assistance, and 
products that are easily accessible and readily understood. This will enable taxpayers to correctly 
fulfil their obligations more easily, thus minimizing the compliance costs of tax administration. The 
MOT has prioritized this area and is seeking to review and assess current practices to identify 
opportunities to strengthen taxpayer services and build taxpayer satisfaction, which is known to 
support improved voluntary compliance. 
 
8.  Effectively dealing with serious incidents of non-compliance. Business operations 
are becoming more complex as the Azerbaijan economy is increasingly internationalized. This 
has brought innovations in business structures, new financial products, and increased use of more 
complex arrangements for tax planning. A complex tax system with a relatively high tax burden 
drives tax avoidance and evasion, which in turn contribute to more aggressive tax planning. In 
addition, more citizens are being brought into the tax net, and emerging new business practices, 
including  an  expanding  e-commerce  sector,  have  heightened  complexity.  These  factors 
contribute to the need for more effective compliance risk management. The tax authority should 
have in place strategies and structures to closely monitor and manage non-compliance with tax 
law. The traditional approach, largely involving one-to-one interventions to obtain compliance and 
collect  taxes,  remains  costly  and  ineffective.  The  President  of  the  Republic  of  Azerbaijan 
approved a resolution on tax reforms in August 2016 to enhance the risk management system, 
increase scope of e-audit for large taxpayers, and improve regulations on all forms of tax

3 
inspections,  among  other  things.6 Despite  these  actions,  non-compliance  with  tax  laws  is 
considered high and largely unchecked, and business processes for tax administration and tax 
arrears management and collection are still inefficient. 
 
9.  Tax revenue modeling and policy analysis. In order to manage public finance prudently, 
revenue forecasts are essential to assess budget planning and management processes and 
estimate the impact of tax expenditures on revenues. Revenue forecasts define the budget 
envelope and form the basis for effective mid- to long-term planning, and transparency of the 
forecasting process is key to creating accountability in revenue collection. The multi-year budget 
should be based on a sound revenue model and methodology that can provide a platform with 
robust fiscal rubrics. The MOF needs to develop the capacity to evaluate, review, and analyze 
revenue  forecasting  models;  to  estimate  tax  expenditure  through  microsimulation  model 
estimations; and to determine the welfare effects of tax expenditures. 
 
10.  Priority reform areas. The need to build a knowledge-based economy has set a new 
agenda for tax authorities, including: enhancing the regulatory role of tax policy; creating an 
affordable, transparent, and attractive tax environment; upgrading tax administration; improving 
services  for  entrepreneurs;  and  establishing  modern  corporate  governance.  An  ADB-
administered TA currently covers some of these areas.7 These reforms also strengthen the policy 
content that falls under the coverage of subprogram 2 of the Improving Governance and Public 
Sector Efficiency Program, scheduled for approval in 2019. 8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact will be the non-oil fiscal position improved. The outcome will be tax policy and 
compliance administration strengthened.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
12.  Output  1:  Human  resource  and  organizational  performance  management 
strengthened. Drawing on ongoing work in tax administration and a comprehensive diagnostic 
study of tax administration conducted by an ADB-administered TA (footnote 7), the TA will support 
the MOT by providing technical advice to (i) develop and implement a leadership development 
program to build a performance management culture and (ii) develop and implement a well-
designed competency management system to strengthen staff recruitment and development. 
This work will include (i) a leadership development program and staff consultations to identify and 
implement ways to better manage performance and address staff concerns and (ii) a pilot study 
and recommendation in selected areas of tax administration (e.g. arrears collection, compliance 
risk management, and tax appeals) to develop and implement a competency management 
framework. The TA will draw from international practices and solutions that could work in the 
Azerbaijan context to address issues or deficiencies in this reform area.

13.  Output 2: Taxpayer services improved. The TA will help the MOT by providing technical 
advice to improve taxpayer voluntary compliance with improved taxpayer support through an 
effective stakeholder consultation program and user-centered design of taxpayer interactions and 
services.  This  work  will  include  (i)  diagnostic  review  of  taxpayer  services,  including  tax 
administration  information  systems,  identifying  digital  opportunities  to  improve  overall  tax 
administration management; (ii) recommendations to improve taxpayer voluntary compliance with 
improved taxpayer support and services, including user-centered design of taxpayer interactions 
and services; and (iii) improving an ongoing stakeholder consultation program.  
 
14.  Output 3: Taxpayer compliance improved by dealing more effectively with serious 
incidents of non-compliance. The TA will support the MOT by providing technical advice to 
improve compliance by dealing more effectively with serious incidents of non-compliance such 
as: (i) reducing the negative impact and improving control of the hidden or shadow economy; (ii) 
building industry-based knowledge and audit capability; and (iii) arresting the growth of arrears 
and building a payment culture. This work will include (i) a research study on the shadow economy; 
(ii) recommendations on ways to control the shadow economy; (iii) trainings for various audit 
techniques, including indirect methods and industry-specific tax audit and risk-based approaches 
to tax collection; and (iv) conducting study tours on VAT incentive schemes such as partial refunds 
and lotteries, and use of fiscal tools. 
 
15.  Output 4: Fiscal management enhanced through improved fiscal modeling. The TA 
will help the MOF to: (i) revise revenue forecasting models for each type of taxation; (ii) develop 
the 2020–2030 fiscal model, which projects financial performance and the financial position of the 
government over a medium-term horizon; (iii) develop models to estimate tax expenditure through 
microsimulation model estimations; (iv) develop models to determine the welfare (economic) 
effects of tax expenditures; and (v) conduct training on tax policy analysis with the aim of 
enhancing the capacity of MOF officials, including female officials. 
 
16.  The TA will support the engagement of international and national experts in tax policy and 
administration.  The  TA  has  coordinated  and  builds  upon  engagement  provided  by  other 
development  partners.  The  European  Union  welcomed  ADB  initiatives  to  support  tax 
administration, including e-audit and human resource management, and agreed to seek further 
coordination,  including  international  taxation  and  aligning  transfer  pricing  legislation  with 
international  standards.  The  World  Bank  is  conducting  a  capacity  development  needs 
assessment by using its tax administration diagnostic tool. The Centre for Tax Policy and 
Administration of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the 
Global Forum on Transparency and Exchange of Information for Tax Purposes have expressed 
their support to capacity development activities. The OECD KOREA Policy Centre agreed to 
provide support and collaborate on capacity development activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $600,000, of which (i) $100,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and (ii) $500,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund  
administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The Republic of Korea 
e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund will finance operational expenses and will not be used 
for (i) civil works, (ii) procurement of large-scale equipment, (iii) permanent staffing costs, or (iv) 
the hiring of staff consultants. The MOT will provide counterpart support in the form of staff time, 
office space, office supplies, secretarial assistance, domestic transportation, and other in-kind 
contributions.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB will administer the TA through its Central and West Asia Department’s Public 
Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division, which will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants; organize discussions; and provide staff to act as resource persons as required. 
ADB’s Azerbaijan Resident Mission will assign staff to join the TA implementation team. TA 
implementation will be coordinated with the SDCC and other ADB departments as appropriate.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund and (ii) the provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$100,000 on a grant basis to the Government of Azerbaijan for Strengthening Tax Policy and 
Administration Capacity, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
